your API and a server-side runtime for executing queries by using a type system you define for your data graph QL isn't
tied to any specific database or storage engine and this is instead backed by your existing code and data so let's
unpack that a bit because I think there's often some misunderstandings about graph QL and what it is when I'm
on the field a lot of times I hear people say graph QL isn't that what I need to work with graph databases nope
graph QL has nothing to do with graph databases you can use graph QL to work
with content that's inside of graph databases but graph QL is completely technology agnostic it doesn't care what
kind of database or data storage layer you're using at all it is just a specification that says here is how
clients should communicate with this API here are the data types that are allowed
to be passed back and forth the shape of that data here are the queries that the client is allowed to use and what fields
the client is allowed to ask for in response to those queries for fulfilling the different data types and also here
are the mutations that the client can affect against the API that's it and you
